content.text: Calculate the gravitational potential energy of the ball relative to the concrete path
gravitational potential energy =   .........
Calculate the kinetic energy of the ball immediately after it strikes the concrete path
kinetic energy =   .........
Show that the change in momentum of the ball when it bounces off the path is \(5.2 \text{kg m / s}\)
The ball is in contact with the path for 0.25 s
Calculate the average resultant force on the ball when it is in contact with the path
The girl releases the ball and it falls towards the path. The ball strikes the path and bounces vertically upwards
Fig. 1.1 shows the ball falling towards the path
The speed of the ball immediately before it strikes the path is \(14 \text{m / s}\)
The speed of the ball immediately after it strikes the path is \(12 \text{m / s}\)
A girl holds a rubber ball out of a window of a tall building. The mass of the ball is \(0.20 \text{kg}\). The ball is at rest \(10 \text{m}\) above a concrete path
Thermal energy is conducted through all solids by lattice vibrations
Describe **one** other way in which thermal energy is conducted through the copper
The outside surface of the cooking pan is kept clean by regular polishing
Explain **one** other advantage of keeping the surface of the pan shiny
The thermal energy passes into the water through the base of the pan
Identify the main method by which thermal energy is transferred throughout the water
A copper cooking pan contains water. Fig. 2.1 shows the pan on a hotplate of a cooker
Copper is a metal
Explain, in terms of particles, why it is difficult to compress liquids
Show that the pressure due to the water at the base of the block is approximately \(850 \text{Pa}\)
Calculate the force \(F\) on the base of the block caused by the pressure given in **(b)**(i)
F =
Force \(F\) is equal to the weight of the block
Calculate the mass of the block
mass =
Fig. 3.1 shows a rectangular block floating in water. The density of the water is \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\)
The area of the base of the block is \(0.014 \text{m}^2\). The base of the block is at a depth of \(0.087 \text{m}\) below the surface of the water
Liquids are difficult to compress whereas gases can be compressed easily
State what is meant by centre of gravity
Explain why the radio transmitter without the wires is a very unstable structure
The centre of gravity G is shown on Fig. 4.1
On Fig. 4.1, mark an arrow to show the force \(T\) exerted by wire W on the transmitter.
The force \(T\) produces a moment on the transmitter about its base
Describe how the moment produced by \(T\) is calculated and indicate on Fig. 4.1 what is meant by any other terms in the description
Wire W is under tension and it exerts a force \(T\) on the transmitter
The radio transmitter uses radio waves to transmit radio and television programmes
State one other use of radio waves

A radio transmitter is a very tall, thin cylinder. It is prevented from falling over by wires which have one end fixed to the transmitter and the other end fixed in the ground. The ends of the wires in the ground are a long distance from the transmitter
Fig. 4.1 shows the transmitter and two of the wires
Describe **one** method of generating electrical power from energy stored in water
For the method you chose in (a), state **one** advantage and **one** disadvantage of generating electricity this way
advantage
disadvantage
State **two** methods of generating electrical power for which the main source of energy is **not** the Sun
Many methods of generating electrical power involve the use of water
By drawing on Fig. 6.1, locate the image of the page produced by the lens and label it I.
Using Fig. 6.1, determine the actual distance of image I from the lens
actual distance from lens =   .........
A length of \(1.0 \text{cm}\) on the scale diagram represents an actual length of \(5.0 \text{cm}\)
Converging lenses can be used as magnifying glasses
State whether the image produced when a lens is used as a magnifying glass is real or virtual. Explain why
Suggest how someone who is long-sighted may benefit from using a converging lens
A page of printed text is placed \(18 \text{cm}\) from a converging lens of focal length \(35 \text{cm}\)
Fig. 6.1 is a scale diagram of the arrangement with each of the two principal focuses (focal points) of the lens labelled F
A plastic rod is uncharged
When the rod is rubbed with a woollen cloth, the rod becomes negatively charged
Explain, in terms of particles, why the rod becomes negatively charged
State what is meant by an electric field
On Fig. 7.1, draw the pattern of the electric field surrounding sphere S and indicate its direction
Fig. 7.1 shows a negatively charged metal sphere S
There is an electric field surrounding S
Fig. 7.2 shows a small negative charge Z placed near to sphere S
Charge Z experiences a force due to the electric field surrounding S
On Fig. 7.2, draw an arrow to show the direction of this force on Z
the magnitude \(X\) of the charge that flows through P in 600 s
the resistance of the cylinder of modelling clay
Calculate:
The cylinder is removed from the circuit and replaced with a new cylinder made of the same modelling clay
The new cylinder is twice the length and has half the cross-sectional area of the first cylinder
Calculate the time that it now takes for a charge of magnitude \(X\) to flow through resistor P
A cylinder is made of modelling clay. The modelling clay is an electrical conductor
Fig. 8.1 shows the cylinder
The cylinder is connected into a circuit
Fig. 8.2 shows that the circuit also includes a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 9.0V and a resistor P
Fig. 8.2
The resistance of P is \(4.0 \Omega\). The current in P is \(1.5 \text{A}\)
State how the composition of a nucleus of americium-241 differs from that of a nucleus of americium-242
An atom of a different element has a nucleon number of 241
State two differences between the composition of a nucleus of this atom and a nucleus of americium-241
Americium-241 is the isotope of the element americium that has the nucleon number (mass number) 241
Complete the equation for this decay
One reason for using an isotope that emits \(\alpha\)-particles in a smoke detector is that \(\alpha\)-particles are more strongly ionising than beta-particles (\(\beta\)-particles)
Explain why \(\alpha\)-particles are more strongly ionising than \(\beta\)-particles
The isotope of neptunium produced by americium-241 is also radioactive
The decay of this isotope of neptunium produces an isotope of protactinium which decays by \(\beta\)-emission. \(\beta\)-particles are more penetrating than \(\alpha\)-particles
The half-life of neptunium is longer than two million years
Using this information, explain the advantage of this long half-life for the use and safe disposal of a household smoke alarm
Americium-241 decays to an isotope of neptunium (Np) by alpha-particle (\(\alpha\)-particle) emission
Many household smoke alarms contain a sample of the radioactive isotope americium-241 (Am)
Stable stars transfer energy into space by emitting electromagnetic radiation from their surfaces
Describe what happens in the core of a stable star to release energy that is eventually transferred into space
Describe how the observed light is different from when it was emitted
State the quantity that astronomers use to determine the speed at which the galaxy is moving away
On the Earth, light from a distant galaxy is observed and analysed by astronomers. This information is used to determine the speed at which the galaxy is moving away from the Earth
Calculate the distance from the Earth of a galaxy that is moving away at a speed of \(1.3 \times 10^{7} \text{m/s}\)
distance =   .........
Calculate an estimate for the age of the Universe. Give your answer in years
age of the Universe =   .........  years
The Hubble constant \(H_0\) is equal to \(2.2 \times 10^{-18}\) per second
The Milky Way is one of many billions of galaxies. Each galaxy contains many billions of stable stars
